Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Seismic Study of the Galicia S Detachment
Award.AbstractNarration: Ocean basins such as the Atlantic are the end products of a process that begins with continental rifts such as East Africa, passes through a young ocean basin phase thought to be typified by the modern Red Sea, and ends with a broader ocean basin produced over many millions of years by seafloor spreading ? a process by which new ocean floor is created by magmatic and tectonic processes at mid-ocean ridges. Though the process is understood in an general way, the details of its earliest stages are poorly known because the geologic evidence is obscured by overlying sediments, massive volcanism associated with early rifting, and, in most places, thick deposits of salt. Located in the eastern North Atlantic, Galicia, is an exception, where rifting occurred with little volcanism, and there is no overlying salt. For that reason, it is an ideal locality for a strong international team to carry out this three-dimensional seismic reflection survey to image the early-formed geologic structure. Among the many broader impacts of this project are its strong international collaboration, participation by undergraduate students as well as a graduate student and a post-doctoral fellow, and the contribution of important new data to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Passive margins that develop along the Earth’s continents are the end product of continental rifting, a major component of plate tectonics. As such, passive margins preserve a record of the history of continental break-up and the processes that accompany it. The Deep Galicia Margin, west of Iberia, is an ideal setting to study this. The principal objective of this project was to make the 3D seismic observations necessary to achieve major progress in our understanding of the processes (geodynamic, tectonic, sedimentological, structural) that occur during continental extension and breakup, through the collection and analysis of a combined 3D seismic reflection and wide-angle dataset over the type-example magma-poor margin west of Iberia, in order to test kinematic and dynamic models for continental extension. Understanding the rifting process also constrains lithospheric mechanics and strength and the thermal structure of the upper mantle, with implications for other settings experiencing intracontinental rifting (e.g. the East African Rift and the Aegean region), mountain building (which inherit fabrics generated during rifting) and mid-ocean ridges.

This NSF project supported six graduate students and two primary investigators at Rice University, in cooperation with several collaborators in the US, United Kingdom, Spain, and Germany. The main activities of the Rice research group focused on seismic processing of the data to help construct the 3D seismic reflection volume, and ultimately, to interpret and analyze the 3D volume to understand the detailed structural, stratigraphic, and compositional make-up of the Galicia Margin. Major discoveries include:

(1) Improved imaging of the mantle, the faulted crust, overlying sediments along this margin, and their associated structures. Preliminary velocity models help to clarify the variations in composition, in tandem with wide-angle seismic studies.

(2) Confirming the continuity and resolving the character of a major detachment fault that accommodated continental thinning during extension. This fault extends 60 km in the east-west direction and across at least the entire 20 km north-south distance of the survey area. It is characterized by prominent linear ridges (corrugations) that are thought to denote the direction of fault slip (much like glacial striations on polished rock). The fault is also spatially complex, defined by two reflectors that are thought to encompass fault rock and gouge derived from plucking and fragmentation of the surrounding rocks; this fault rock thickness appears to increase to the west with increasing fault displacement. This is the first time any major fault zone has been observed in such detail completely in the subsurface.

(3) Resolving the structure and evolution of a large uplifted ridge that lies to the west of the thinned continental crust. Referred to as the Peridotite Ridge, this elongate feature is composed of mantle rock that was exposed during continental extension, and then uplifted. The 3D seismic volume reveals two key faults that appear to have accommodated uplift of the ridge, and also enabled slope failure, producing large volumes of landslide debris that have accumulated along its flanks.

(4) The thinned continental crust also appears to have undergone local landsliding along extensional faults, which resulted in thrust faulting at the very toe of the continental margin.  This is the first documentation of thrust faulting in this particular setting, but it is thought to be a process active through gravitational spreading at other passive margins.

(5) Westward extensions of two lines that traverse the seismic volume reveal the character of the seafloor that defines the “ocean-continent transition”. Two low-lying regions with rough seafloor are flanked by higher relief and smoother ridges. The low-lying regions appear to be capped by basalts consistent with oceanic crust, whereas the smoother ridges are more characteristic of exposed peridotite similar to the more extensive peridotite ridge. This is the first evidence for the location and nature of the onset of oceanic spreading in this setting.

This project has contributed scientifically to our understanding of how passive margins develop and the onset of oceanic spreading. It has provided training to six students directly, and to many other students through classroom projects using the 3D seismic data. Students and PIs have given many presentations to communicate the exciting results of this study, and published the first two of several papers on the project.  And the 3D seismic data set is available to the public via the University of Texas Institute of Geophysics seismic portal.
